reviewText: Geez....way back THEN, I absolutely loved Alice. Thirty years later it all looks so immature and ridiculous. His theatrical broadway R & R antics just look wimpy. I still think Alice is probably a pretty cool guy, and I love HEARING his older music (KILLER is still his best album), but this DVD really sucks. It probably deserves 1 star, but I can't bear to give Alice a failing grade, so out of the kindness of my heart, I'll give him 2 stars. Stay away from this DVD.Oh yeah......they promote this DVD as extra shocking and gross........it's not, compared to today's standards. This whole disc just seems silly.

reviewText: Ok, here's the deal. For the most part, all the reviews written thus far for this DVD are correct. You have to remember, the year was 1973 when this concert was being done. What kind of stage performances were the norm back then, what was the typical stage setup, what was the culture of the country? By today's standards this concert is a cheesey, but fun rock 'n roll show. It's basically a straight foward concert, not a big theatrical production. During the commentary, Alice says that Unfinished Sweet was really the first theatrical performance done during any of their concerts, and it wasn't that big of a deal. The bottom line is, this concert shows you where the band actually came from. Even though Babies was their 6th album, it was their mainstream breakthrough album. In 1973 they spent 1.4 million putting this show on, and made 4.3 million off of it. This was back in the day when a ticket was only a few dollars. The footage was the typical music video styling for the era, meaning that the camera men really didn't know how to capture the performance of a concert. They had a lot of close ups on Alice's face, not much of the rest of the band, and a lot of zooming in and out. This was actually quite annoying, because there was a lot more going on in the show than just the armpit hair growing out of Alice's arm. And when Alice wasn't really doing anything, the camera men kept shooting him, even though his back was turned and he was drinking cola. This, in my opinion, was amaturish camera work. The sound remix was decent. It was actually better than the mix used on the Billion Dollar Babies SE album, which included the live concert music taken from this tour. The concert itself was dark. There wasn't a lot of lighting used since their lighting idea was more like a vegas light show rather than a bunch of gel colored projections. Because of the camera work and the few spotlights that were shown down upon Alice, this kind of made things boring from time to time, because the lights that were set up weren't used very often. It also made the rest of the band hard to see. Anyone that knows anything knows that lighting helps set the mood and sell the image. Again, 1973... typical stage performances weren't all the detailed. The video skits were quite enjoyable in my opinion, but I knew first hand, and expected them to be cheesey, which they were, so I wasn't dissappointed in them. I actually found them humorous in a subtle manner. Overall, it's a fun concert. Would have been great to have been there. But still, the best Alice concert DVD to date, by far, is the Brutally Live DVD. It's not the theatrical Welcome to my Nightmare style of a show, but there are some theatrics. What puts that DVD over the top is the outstanding musicianship, excellent sound, and by this time the camera crew and lighting, and director actually knew what they were doing.

reviewText: I can't say I expected a lot with this release, as I never do expect much with "suddenly unearthed" early footage or recordings of my favorite old bands. But I had to bite on this one. If you are a fan of the old Cooper band (the only one that matters), then this is pretty exciting to watch, as it is the only footage I know of from that era, at least professionally filmed. For anybody, like me, who did witness the bizarre spectacle of the early tours, this is a nice reminder, since it's all there - the mannequins, the stabbed baby dolls, the snake, the guillotine. And while only about an hour in length (if you choose the "view concert only" option), the band does cover a lot of great tunes from the early repertoire. Secondly, the sound is superb, so even as a live album, this is worth it. But to see a young and snarling Alice Cooper in his prime - well, it made me remember exactly why parents and clergy the world over considered this guy the second coming of Satan - and we all loved it!! Hey, I only paid nine bucks for this, so while not perfect, it's definitely worth having.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Billion Dollar Babies tour was the high water mark for Alice Cooper.  In 1973, I had just turned 18 and Alice Cooper was "the band".  I pretty much went to every concert in my high school days, including this tour.  Bowie, Tull, John, Zep- I saw em all.  And Coop was at the top.  Even though he didn't have much of a voice, the band wasn't all that tight, what they created was ahead of their time.Having said all that, watching this dvd with the perspective of now being 54, was to use a 60's term- a trip.  It's amazing how things don't seem as impressive with more than 3 decades of hindsight.  This is no exception.  Like they say, you had to be there.  Watching it on dvd just wasn't the same.The sound was just ok.  The camera work- so so.  And the skits were just crap.  I did enjoy the commentary, so you do want to watch it once without and then with commentary and that will at least make your purchase of this dvd worthwhile.I guess the phrase you can never go home still rings true.  RIP Alice.  Time to  move on.
summary: Only for the hard core Cooper Fans

Most of his songs are their gretest hits and Im glad that this great creepy concert is from the 70's because that the main reason that I bought this dvd. EVEN IF THEY ARE BETTER!!!!!The only things that I didn't like was that "Welcome to my Nighmare" wasn't here and "School's Out" was very interrupted by fights and several things.WARNING: This concert is interrupted by a boring movie on each song that plays in the beginig or in the end of the song, BUT you can skip it by selecting in the special features "Play Concert Only" option.P.S: Don't lisen to the reviewer above me! This dvd is COOL!!!

reviewText: I expected a concert video similar to what is usually released today, but I was surprised to see that the DVD is comprised of a live show and a kookie storyline that wraps around it, similar to the Monkees' Head or the Beatles Yellow Submarine.The movie part of it revolves around a crazy German director who chases down the Alice Cooper Band because they ruined his movie. The opening skit is priceless, but after that it gets a little rough. The live performance highlight the group at the pinnacle of their career, and of course they sound great.Although the DVD boasts the typical AC theatrics, they really don't come into play until the last half of the set. You do have the option to watch the performance only. Bonuses include Alice commentary, trailers, photo galleries, and outtakes

reviewText: In recent months, I have become a crazy Alice Cooper fan, listening to "Billion Dollar Babies" especially on repeat. This DVD concert was filmed during this period in both Dallas and Houston, TX. Great, old-school coop footage! This shows how good the original band was and also gives you a bird's-eye-view of all the best antics on-stage. The intermingled movie is just dumb. I watched it once but now I just skip through and watch all the songs.

reviewText: The very first record album I bought was "Welcome To My Nightmare" by the solo artist Alice Cooper.  I was familiar with the radio hits and a friend had the "Greatest Hits" album but I really knew nothing of the Alice Cooper Group other than stories revealed years later.  I heard about this dvd and asked for it as a Christmas present and finally got around to watching it last night.  This concert or movie is over 30 years old. Please keep that in mind.  If you are looking for something that has been recorded in the last decade, you will not find it here.  This is just a piece of history of a band that was firing on all cylinders, definitely in their prime.  I needed to see the guillotine scene to fully understand what made this band such a monster live act.  The movie is hurt by the comedy attempts of a mad director but the bright side is you can choose to watch only the concert and that is why this is here.  The sound may not be state of the art but how could one expect that from something so old and a different technology back then.  Open up your minds and eyes and see what Alice Cooper the band was really about.  I wasn't familiar with all the songs but "Elected", "Under My Wheels". "18", and "Billion Dollar Babies " are here and that is enough for me.  I hate "Easter Eggs" on dvds.  Why should I have to search for the secret to access a bonus feature.  I have never understood that.  Anyway, well worth the money.  See where Kiss, Marilyn Manson, & Twisted Sister got inspired.
summary: I have always heard of their great show, now I get a chance to actually see it

reviewText: The best thing about this is the 'Play Concert Only' option.I love this band. It's a shame they didn't stay together longer.Their albums from this time period are among the best of all time.I've seen the bootleg version and the old movie clips areno better than the lousy comedy sketches.The comedy sketches are neither funny or entertaining.I agree with 'moulty'in that this band was so good,it was criminal to break them up.On the good side, the audio/video is a hell of a lot better than the bootleg.You can actually see the band(Michael Bruce,Dennis Dunaway,Neal Smith and Glen Buxton)instead of darkness behind Alice.The concert footage is fabulous.Probably the best we'll seefrom this era.I wish they showed the group more though.I saw this concert in '73(showing my age huh?),and it was truly'LEGENDARY'!!!If you like Alice, you'll love this to death.

reviewText: Let's start with the ugly: The "story" that wraps around the concert sequences is beyond lame, populated with actors who make the denizens of early John Waters' films look Oscar-worthy.We begin with the boys of the Alice Cooper group trashing and storming off a movie set where they were forced to wear ridiculous powder wigs and sing showtunes. This causes the tempermental and vengeful European director and his giant Nordic assistant to try and hunt down "The Cooper Gang". The only redeemable moment in this mess is when the boys escape via elephant (don't ask) Monkees-style in fast-motion while "Halo of Flies" plays in the background.Now, the bad: While it's great that Shout! Factory put this out and probably did their best with the source elements, there is plenty of dirt, debris and blemishes on the print. Those expecting Hi-Def remastering and pristine picture and sound quality will be sorely disappointed.Which brings us to the good: At least by accessing the Special Features, you can choose the "Play Concert Only" option and spare yourself the pain of the "comedy" segments.The concert itself, the 1973 Billion Dollar Babies Tour, is fantastic and must-see viewing for fans of the Alice Cooper Group. Alice sports a pair of thigh-high leopard print boots over a tattered leotard while the band look sharp in white sequined suits. There is never a dull moment as Alice frolics and molests various dismembered female mannequin bodyparts; is chased by a crazed dentist, then himself chases a dancing molar with a giant toothbrush; threatens a cocky audience member; pins a giant insect to his crotch; picks out female audience members to kiss while avoiding the jailbait; and is decapitated by a guillotine.The majority of the set list is understandably culled from "Billion Dollar Babies", though we are treated to "Eighteen", "Under My Wheels" and an abbreviated "Dead Babies". "My Stars" comes off much better here than on the "School's Out" album and is accompanied by an elaborate (for 1973) light show.My favorite moments include the "Raped and Freezin'/No More Mr. Nice Guy" medley, which begins with Alice, Michael, Glen and Dennis all standing shoulder-to-shoulder rocking out--something we usually never got to see as the band always had their usual positions--while Neal works his magic from a specially-built drum kit platform; and "Sick Things" which Alice performs while Kuchina the snake wraps herself around him (he actually needs to be "rescued" when the reptile obscures his face and he can't project into the mic). It ends when Alice raises the American flag and the band pummel a Richard Nixon lookalike and carry him offstage before they take their well-deserved final bows.Despite the problems of this DVD, any fan of the Alice Coooper group needs to see this. I only wish we had such a great video document of the "Killer" tour as the "Love It to Death/Killer" era with Alice in the spider makeup is my favorite and when I believe the boys were at their most creative.
summary: The Good, The Bad and the Ugly
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, unless you were hoping that Alice Cooper would make a movie that would complete some sort of strange trilogy with "Help!" by the Beatles and "Head" by the Monkees, my best advice with this DVD is to go directly to the Special Features and find where it says just to play the concert.  That is because except for the opening where Alice and the band dress up in white and do "The Lady is a Tramp" on a soundstage, the comedic interludes are simply wretched.  The best that can be said for them is that they would suffice as bathroom breaks or opportunities to raid the refrigeration and switch the laundry from the washer to the dryer.  But provide entertainment value they do not (there is some lame excuse about the director being upset when the band destroys his set after performing the aforementioned music number, but it hardly justifies the pitiful scenes that follow).The "Billion Dollar Babies" Tour of 1973 was when Alice Cooper was at the top of the mountain, and the chief value of "Good to See You Again, Alice Cooper" is that it documents the stage show with the big snake, the guillotine, and the rest of the props that threatened to make the music incidental to the experience.  Filmed deep in the heart of Texas at Dallas and Houston, on April 28 and 29 respectively, this concert film reminds us that there was more to Alice Cooper that the shock theater aspects.  Before Jim Steinman started writing operatic rock songs for Meatloaf and providing the paradigmatic examples of these particular art form, it was Alice Cooper on "Billion Dollar Babies" that were claiming that particular patch of musical territory, as amply demonstrated by "Elected," "Billion Dollar Babies," and "Hello, Hooray."  Those actually end up being the first three songs in the concert, and then the band goes back to their first hit, "I'm Eighteen," which proves they had been working towards their goal for some time (to wit, ever since Bob Ezrin became their producer).  In terms of other quantifiable hits, "No More Mr. Nice Guy" pop up in the middle, and then "School's Out" and "Under My Wheels" are saved for the big finish.  To make sure parents are suitably offended, "Raped and Freezin'," "Sick Things," "Dead Babies" and "I Love the Dead" are thrown into the mix.What I remember about Alice Cooper is that I liked the music, especially when turned up loud, and that I did not really care about the lyrics.  After all, you can make an argument that "Dead Babies" is a sort of public service announcement, but when you watch "Good to See You Again" there should be moments when you think Cooper is at least trying to go too far, even if you think he never gets there (be fair when you do this, and think in terms of what things were like in the 1970s and not judge Alice Cooper by their progeny, from Kiss to Marilyn Manson and beyond).  At this point in the history of the known universe watching them chop off  the head of Alice Cooper and displaying it to the crowd was as the pinnacle of rock `n' roll stagecraft.  Ultimately, the tacky comedy segments of the movie are counter-balanced by the DVD extras, which include a commentary track by Alice himself, a deleted scene, some original graphics, and a radio spot for the film to go along with the trailer.
summary: Remembering Alice Cooper on stage during the glory days of the "Billion Dollar Babies" Tour
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was filmed over thirty years ago when I was still in Jr High. I would've loved to have been in the audience here for this show. They waited so long to release this that I've kind of gotten use to the more recent videos of Alice which are far more polished and professional.This is enjoyable in an historic light but the truth is the band sounds sloppy at times and as far as theatrics go it was fun then but today it seems a bit dated. I would recommend that newer fans go with Live At Montreaux dvd or something after Alice's rehab. This is certainly enjoyable in a novel sort of way. This is from what Alice calls his "alcoholic period".Alice appears to forget the words to "Raped and Freezin" and the band seems unaware of which one one is supposed to playing lead or rhythm. The background vocals during "Under My Wheels" are horribly off, and that entire thing about Fred Smoot and the guy on the bicycle is really annoying. This is apparently at the height of the controversy and it's clear that they were riding high on the wave of their notoriety while they ccould, so the theatrics are emphasized here and not musianship. Also the stage lights were too dark during much of the performance. Put the lights on so we can better See You Again, Alice Cooper.
Title: N/A

reviewText: EVERYBODY CAN REMEMBER THE EXACT MOMENT WHEN THEIR ADOLESCENCE WAS INVADED AND FOREVER CONTAMINATED BY ROCK AND ROLL.  IN THE FIFTIES IT WAS ELVIS , IN THE SIXTIES,  THE BEATLES.  AND IN THE SEVENTIES (WHERE MY INNOCENCE FELL) IT WAS THE ALICE COOPER GROUP.  I HAD FIRST HEARD OF ALICE COOPER A FEW YEARS EARLIER WHEN STRAINS OF "KILLER" WOULD SEEP OUT OF MY BROTHERS BEDROOM AND WOULD START ITS INEVITABLE TAKEOVER OF MY MIND , BODY AND SOUL.I MEAN ITS HARD TO GO FROM "SWEET CAROLINE" BY NEIL DIAMOND TO "DEAD BABIES"AND NOT HAVE IT HAVE A PROFOUND EFFECT ON ONES PSYCHY.WHEN " SCHOOLS OUT " OVERTOOK THE AIRWAVES A YEAR LATER I WAS OFFICIALLY A FAN AND READY FOR THE ULTIMATE BAPTISM THAT WOULD COME IN THE FORM OF "BILLION DOLLAR BABIES".THE BILLION DOLLAR BABIES CONCERT TOURWAS THE LARGEST GROSSING TOUR (TO DATE) IN THE HISTORY OF MUSIC. COVERING AN EXHAUSTING 56 CITIES IN 62 DAYS, AN OVERWHELMING SCHEDULE THAT WOULD PUT ALICE COOPER ON THE MAP TO STAY. THIS RECORD WAS TRULY ONE OF ROCKS MOST IMPORTANT AND INFLUENTIAL RELEASES AS IT "SET THE STAGE" SO TO SPEAK FOR WHAT WAS TO FOLLOW. ARTISTS SUCH AS DAVID BOWIE, KISS, MARILYN MANSON AND EVEN PINK FLOYD HAVE CREDITED THE ALICE COOPER GROUP AS INSPIRATION FOR THEIR THEATRICS.BUT WHAT IS MORE IMPORTANT AND CAN NOT BE OVERSHADOWED BY THE VISUALSIS THE MUSIC."HELLO HOORAY", RAISED THE BAR FOR SHOW OPENERS, "ELECTED", "BILLION DOLLAR BABIES" AND "NO MORE MR. NICE GUY" WERE HUGE HITS THEN AND ARE STILL IN CONSTANT ROTATION ON THE RADIO SOME 27 YEARS LATER. "RAPED AND FREEZIN", "UNFINISHED SWEET"AND THE UNDERATED "GENERATION LANDSLIDE" ARE A POWERHOUSE TRIO OF SONGS THAT HELPED PROPELL THE LIVE SHOW FORWARD UNTIL REVISITING THE EARLIER HITS LIKE," UNDER MY WHEELS", "I'M EIGHTEEN" AND THE CLASSIC, "SCHOOLS OUT"."SICK THINGS " AND  "I LOVE THE DEAD" SERVED AS THE SOUNDTRACK TO ONE OF ROCKS MOST SINISTER STAGE MOMENTS. AFTER BEING HUNG AND ELECTROCUTEDIN PREVIOUS SHOWS, THE FORBIDDING GUILLOTINE WAS BY FAR HIS FINAST HOUR.ALL OF THESE SONGS WERE PART OF A CALCULATED EFFORT BY THE ALICE COOPER GROUP AND THEIR "BRIAN EPSTEIN" BOB EZRIN. STARTING WITH "LOVE IT TO DEATH"MORPHING THROUGH "KILLER" AND "SCHOOL'S OUT" AND CULMINATING WITH "BILLION DOLLAR BABIES" ALICE COOPER'S PUBLIC PERSONA CHANGED FROM THE GROUP TO THE MAN. BUT WHAT GOT LOST IN ALL THE THEATRICS AND AMERICAS PERCEPTION OF THEIR NEW PUBLIC ENEMY (OR WAS IT PUBLIC ANIMAL?) WAS THE CREDITING OF SONGWRITING AND CONTRIBUTIONS OF THE OTHER MEMBERS OF THE GROUP.THE UNFAIR PERCEPTION THAT IT WAS "ALL ALICE" LEAD TO THE BANDS DISOLUTION IN '75 AFTER THEY RELEASED "MUSCLE OF LOVE", A TRULY GREAT ROCK RECORD BUT UNFORTUNATELY ONE THAT HAD LESS DIRECTION AND CONCEPT THAN ITS PREDECESSORS.(This was my first concert ever at age 14 and will never forget it.)"BILLION DOLLAR BABIES- DELUXE" ENCOMPASSES ALL THAT WAS GREAT ABOUT THE'70'S YOUTH. GREED, LUST, SEX, DRUGS AND LAST BUT CERTAINLY NOT LEASTROCK AND ROLL. THIS RELEASE IS A MUST NOT ONLY FOR EVERY COOPER FAN'SCOLLECTIONS, BUT ALSO AN IMPORTANT TIMECAPSULE FOR TODAYS' KIDS SO THEY MIGHT UNDERSTAND WHAT IT WAS LIKE WHEN ROCK AND ROLL MEANT SOMETHINGTO THE HOPES AND DREAMS OF TEENAGERS, NOT JUST A WAY FOR CORPORATIONS TO PRODUCE AN ARTIST TO SELL THEIR PRODUCTS...MATT PARISH
summary: Good?  Great To See You Again Alice Cooper !!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'll try to cover new ground that others have not addressed in their reviews. The real reason that this film is so dark according to Brian Nelson, Alice's personal assistant, is the film crew filmed the show with 16mm cameras and then blew the film up to 35mm for theatrical release. This is basic photography 101. When you blow up film like that, the film gets darker.Moulty is right about a lot of things. B$B is clipped. Shout Factory apparently didn't get all the footage or didn't use it. So I guess I'll still have to keep my bootleg DVD when I want to see the complete B$B song.I agree that the filming techniques were poor. Black Oak Arkansas has a DVD out with footage filmed at Royal Albert Hall in England in 1974. That film is excellent, they actually zoom in on the guitarist when they're soloing.I thought Shout Factory would have had the whole concert on film but apparently all they did was edit the skit version so it is not seamless at all.In the actual performance, after Unfinished Suite, stobe lights flashed while "Night on Bald Mountain" was piped through the PA and a bunch roadies came on stage with wheel barrows full of body parts. They would beat each other with the body parts during the stobe light show and then left. Alice then began Sick Things. This is not seen on this film.I'm still glad this came out although the band is still conspicuous by their absence, yet again. They were not interviewed which might have been interesting.The Alice commentary is quite good though.
Title: N/A

reviewText: So happy to see this film has FINALLY been put out as a legit release. I remember umpteen years ago, I think I paid big buck$ for a so-so quality VHS video tape copy of 'Good To See...'. I was one of those true Cooper fans that simply couldn't wait ANY longer to land down a copy of this movie. Saw it in a theater when it first came out in summer, 1974. Highly appreciate this DVD's 'Watch Concert Only' option, although those old B&W snippets of vintage movies are fun to check out WHEN you have time. Tracks that this fan will have edged in the back of his mind for a long time to come are "Hello Hooray", "Billion Dollar Babies", "Elected", the exclusive (hadn't been played out on tour since) "My Stars", "Dead Babies", "I Love The Dead" and "School's Out". Also sort of dug the DVD's opening scene where Alice and band mock the torch song "Lady Is A Tramp". Thirty-three years ago, when this tour took place, the entertainment world was in fact shocked by the show's antics of a scroungy-looking rock star sticking a baby doll at the tip of a sword, humping a store mannequin, necrophilia and a beheading. This WAS excitement (and still is) for those who seek it. The extras are nice to have as well. It's amazing to think JUST how much the world has changed since the notorious 'Billion Dollar Babies' trek had infested the American youth. Prime Shock Rock here just waiting to be fully experienced. An absolute MUST-HAVE.
summary: 'Good To See You Again, Alice Cooper - Live 1973 - Billion Dollar Babies Tour' (Shout! Factory)
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a Alice Cooper fan since the early '70s, I must admit that the Billion Dollar Babies show that made it onto this DVD is fantastic and totally compelling.To me, the ride these guys were on in the years from 1969 to 1974  was really special. They were entirely different from everyone else, churning out garage-rock anthems on a couple of albums per year, and bringing it home as one of the world's biggest concert draws. So why is it that their stage performances remain on shelves somewhere? I don't care about the quality of it - it's historic!!The story-line aspect is fine (for a 1973 spoof), but I'm not likely to watch it again... it's too corny and dated. If they had added (maybe on a second disc) another show or partial shows, that would have been more enjoyable, since there are times (especially during Alice's shock-rock/performance-art moments in the show) that the band's playing becomes quite cacaphonic.. FYI the whole concert can be heard along with Alice's recently added commentary...other reviewers may have mentioned this, and it's the best way to watch this particular show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This a great document of Alice in his prime right before the split from his original bandmates which would lead to the(from a rock'n roll point of view) much inferior"Welcome to my Nightmare" movie.The concert is mixed with some kind of nebulous story wich can fortunately be skipped with the chapter button.Anyway,look at this and see the original madman of decadent rock backed by his great band do all those great rocksongs with Alice in top vocal and theatrical display.Oh! By the way. Alice's audio comment is  a must too.

Title: N/A

reviewText: If Charles Manson killed the hippie's "Summer Of Love", Alice Cooper mocked and humped the corpse. There could have been no better time for Alice Cooper to appear than in the early 70s. I was just a child at the time, standing around shadowy corners of the schoolyard where second hand stories of Alice's gory live act were whispered and traded like gruesome little folklore tales. Our parents tried to protect us, but we would spend amazing amounts of effort sneaking albums and 8-track tapes of Alice around, secretly listening to the forbidden musical gems.  Anybody who saw the band live at this time must have sensed that they were witness to a historical moment in time... a moment that represented American pop-culture's bogus innocence being deflowered. These lovely blood spattered memories are now ours to cherish forever with the DVD release of "Good to See You Again Alice Cooper", available for the first time ever on home video.Two nights of Alice Cooper's notorious 1973 Billion Dollar Babies tour (April 28th in Dallas and April 29th in Houston) were filmed to create this rare 1974 midnight matinee film, and it's a great testament to the riotous live act that made the Alice Cooper Group a threat to concerned parents everywhere. This DVD contains the original cut of the film which includes the band starring in charming little skits scattered amongst the astonishing live footage (The more common version of the film shown in theaters included old film and newsreel footage instead of the skits). A highly amusing moment among these skits features the band playing "The Lady Is a Tramp". Shout! Factory lovingly provides this release with a new high-definition film transfer along with a new Surround Sound mix created from the 16-track master tapes.What uncomfortable items will Alice shove down his pants? What celebrity will be pummeled to a pulp by the band? Will the snake get out of control? Where will all the blood and spittle drip to?  Will security be able to hold Alice back from attacking and brawling with audience members? Will Alice lose his head? The answers to these questions and more are available in "Good to See You Again Alice Cooper - The film that out-grosses them all".
summary: After all these years, it really is good to see this again!
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, let me say that I recommend that anyone into Alice Cooper back in the 70s should buy this DVD. But there is a caveat....Funny. I thought that I'd buy a live performance from this hard rock icon of my teenage years that I (according to my parents) was too young to actually go see during the 70s, and I was sure that I was buying the awesome, spectacular rock show that I was forbidden by my parents to go see when I was in Jr. high. Ultimately the performace in this DVD was pretty corny by today's standards.I actually found myself skipping though a lot of the songs that I thought that I'd be captivated by. Overall, a mediocre performance at best with much less than dazzling theatrics.Then after my first viewing I watched it with Alice's audio commentary turned on. And let me tell you...that watching it with the commentary on is absolutely the way this release was intended to be watched and should be watched. That is the caveat that I mentioned earlier....BE SURE THAT YOU WATCH THIS WITH ALICE'S COMMENTARY ON.If you were an Alice fan (like me) back in the day and you are over 40 (like me), and you really want to enjoy this show, watch it with the audio commentary ON. I'm sure (based on Alice's own commentary!) that Alice would recommend that you do the same.If my expectations for a great theatrical DVD were a let-down, I can say that being able to watch "with Alice" certainly exceeded my expectations.So if you were into Alice back in the day, be sure to watch this with Alice's commentary turned ON during your viewing. (Did I mention that?) It brought my experience to a much higher level.If you are a youngster checking out what your Daddy used to think was cool...perhaps you should watch the DVD first without the commentary (but doing this will only support your current belief that your Dad is a freak), but ultimately be sure to watch it again with the commentary on; it will really give you a better perspective of what was going on in the mind of what at the time was a very unique artist.Buy it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ok....after getting this and not being able to get it to work on any of my players I thought it was because it was damaged but i think its because of the region.Anyway, I finally viewed this at a friends and was appalled.Period! it stinks and is one of the poorest,cheap dvd's I've ever seen.Being an Alice Cooper Fanatic from age 13 and still am, i cried.He's at his worst here in my opinion.I saw Alice in concert back in 1976 and was thrilled.It was totally awesome and very theatrical but this concert is not worth 2 cents even if you're a die hard Coop fan as I am.I wouldn't waste your time or money with this.The sound is terrible and so is the picture quality.It's like a cheap camera set up was used to photo and record using a low budget newbie college student for a camera man hanging a small mic.Alice should be ashamed of himself for having this out in the public.Would the real Alice Cooper please stand up and come forth.Walk away people.
summary: I AM APPALLED AND TOTALLY DISGUSTED .HEART BROKEN TO THE MAX!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a concert from the 1973 Billion Dollar Babies tour and an actual move with a strange plot. Since this was made in 1974, that means it is the ORIGINAL ALICE COOPER GROUP IN THEIR PRIME. Also since it was made in 1974 the actual movie is downright horrible. The concert itself is excellent with all of the band members at their finest. Thank God their is a Play Concert Only option.SPECIAL FEATURES INCLUDE:Commentary by Alice himselfBand biographies with very small printHidden easter eggs.Die hard Alice Cooper fans will love this because it is the only DVD with the ORIGINAL ALICE COOPER BAND.
Title: N/A
